SPEECH.LINE: Giue me the Iron I ſay, and binde him heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Art.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, what neede you be ſo boiſtrous rough?
I will not ſtruggle, I will ſtand ſtone ſtill:
For heauen ſake Hubert let me not be bound:
Nay heare me Hubert, driue theſe men away,
And I will ſit as quiet as a Lambe.
I will not ſtirre, nor winch, nor ſpeake a word,
Nor looke vpon the Iron angerly:
Thruſt but theſe men away, and Ile forgiue you,
What euer torment you do put me too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: Go ſtand within: let me alone with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Exec.
SPEECH.LINE: I am beſt pleas’d to be from ſuch a deede.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Art.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, I then haue chid away my friend,
He hath a ſterne looke, but a gentle heart:
Let him come backe, that his compaſſion may
Giue life to yours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: Come (Boy) prepare your ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Art.
SPEECH.LINE: Is there no remedie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: None, but to loſe your eyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Art.
SPEECH.LINE: O heauen: that there were but a moth in yours,
A graine, a duſt, a gnat, a wandering haire,
Any annoyance in that precious ſenſe:
Then feeling what ſmall things are boyſterous there,
Your vilde intent muſt needs ſeeme horrible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: Is this your promiſe? Go too, hold your toong.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Art.
SPEECH.LINE: Hubert, the vtterance of a brace of tongues,
Muſt needes want pleading for a paire of eyes:
Let me not hold my tongue: let me not Hubert,
Or Hubert, if you will cut out my tongue,
So I may keepe mine eyes. O ſpare mine eyes,
Though to no vſe, but ſtill to looke on you.
Lœ, by my troth, the Inſtrument is cold,
And would not harme me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: I can heate it, Boy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Art.
SPEECH.LINE: No, in good ſooth: the fire is dead with griefe,
Being create for comfort, to be vs’d
In vndeſerued extreames: See elſe your ſelfe,
There is no malice in this burning cole,
The breath of heauen, hath blowne his ſpirit out,
And ſtrew’d repentant aſhes on his head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: But with my breath I can reuiue it Boy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Art.
SPEECH.LINE: And if you do, you will but make it bluſh,
And glow with ſhame of your proceedings, Hubert:
Nay, it perchance will ſparkle in your eyes:
And, like a dogge that is compell’d to ﬁght,
Snatch at his Maſter that doth tarre him on.
All things that you ſhould vſe to do me wrong
Deny their ofﬁce: onely you do lacke
That mercie, which ﬁerce ﬁre, and Iron extends,
Creatures of note for mercy, lacking vſes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, ſee to liue: I will not touch thine eye,
For all the Treaſure that thine Vnckle owes,
Yet am I ſworne, and I did purpoſe, Boy,
With this ſame very Iron, to burne them out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Art.
SPEECH.LINE: O now you looke like Hubert. All this while
You were diſguis’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace: no more. Adieu,
Your Vnckle muſt not know but you are dead.
Ile fill theſe dogged Spies with falſe reports:
And, pretty childe, ſleepe doubtleſſe, and ſecure,
That Hubert for the wealth of all the world,
Will not offend thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Art.
SPEECH.LINE: O heauen! I thanke you Hubert.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: Silence, no more; go cloſely in with mee,
Much danger do I vndergo for thee.Exeunt

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Iohn, Pembroke, Salisbury, and other Lordes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere once againe we ſit: once againſt crown’d
And look’d vpon, I hope, with chearefull eyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pem.
SPEECH.LINE: This once again (but that your Highnes pleas’d)
Was once ſuperfluous: you were Crown’d before,
And that high Royalty was nere pluck’d off:
The faiths of men, nere ſtained with reuolt:
Freſh expeƈtation troubled not the Land
With any long’d-for-change, or better State.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: Therefore, to be poſſeſſ’d with double pompe,
To guard a Title, that was rich before;
To gilde reﬁned Gold, to paint the Lilly;
To throw a perfume on the Violet,
To ſmooth the yce, or adde another hew
Vnto the Raine-bow; or with Taper-light
To ſeeke the beauteous eye of heauen to garniſh,
Is waſtefull, and ridiculous exceſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pem.
SPEECH.LINE: But that your Royall pleaſure muſt be done,
This aƈte, is as an ancient tale new told,
And, in the laſt repeating, troubleſome,
Being vrged at a time vnſeaſonable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: In this the Anticke, and well noted face
Of plaine old forme, is much diſﬁgured,
And like a ſhiﬅed winde vnto a ſaile,
It makes the courſe of thoughts to fetch about,
Startles, and frights conſideration:
Makes ſound opinion ſicke, and truth ſuſpeƈted,
For putting on ſo new a faſhion’d robe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pem.
SPEECH.LINE: When Workemen ſtriue to do better then wel,
They do confound their ſkill in couetouſneſſe,
And oﬅentimes excuſing of a fault,
Doth make the fault the worſe by th’ excuſe:
As patches ſet vpon a little breach,
Diſcredite more in hiding of the fault,
Then did the fault before it was ſo patch’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: To this effeƈt, before you were new crown’d
We breath’d our Councell: but it pleas’d your Highnes
To ouer-beare it, and we are all well pleas’d,
Since all, and euery part of what we would
Doth make a ſtand, at what your Highneſſe will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SPEECH.LINE: Some reaſons of this double Corronation
I haue poſſeſt you with, and thinke them ſtrong.
And more, more ſtrong, then leſſer is my feare
I ſhall indue you with: Meane time, but aske
What you would haue reform’d, that is not well,
And well ſhall you perceiue, how willingly
I will both heare, and grant you your requeſts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pem.
SPEECH.LINE: Then I, as one that am the tongue of theſe
To ſound the purpoſes of all their hearts,
Both for my ſelfe, and them: but chiefe of all
Your ſafety: for the which, my ſelfe and them
Bend their beſt ſtudies, heartily requeſt
Th’ infranchiſement of Arthur, whoſe reſtraint
Doth moue the murmuring lips of diſcontent
To breake into this dangerous argument.
If what in reſt you haue, in right you hold,
Why then your feares, which (as they ſay) attend
The ſteppes of wrong, ſhould moue you to mew vp
Your tender kinſman, and to choake his dayes
With barbarous ignorance, and deny his youth
The rich aduantage of good exerciſe,
That the times enemies may not haue this
To grace occaſions: let it be our ſuite,
That you haue bid vs aske his libertie,
Which for our goods, we do no further aske,
Then, whereupon our weale on you depending,
Counts it your weale: he haue his liberty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Let it be ſo: I do commit his youth
To your direƈtion: Hubert, what newes with you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pem.
SPEECH.LINE: This is the man ſhould do the bloody deed:
He ſhew’d his warrant to a friend of mine,
The image of a wicked heynous fault
Liues in his eye: that cloſe aſpeƈt of his,
Do ſhew the mood of a much troubled breſt,
And I do fearefully beleeue ’tis done,
What we ſo fear’d he had a charge to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: The colour of the King doth come, and go
Betweene his purpoſe and his conſcience,
Like Heralds ’twixt two dreadfull battailes ſet:
His paſſion is ſo ripe, it needs mu’t breake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pem.
SPEECH.LINE: And when it breakes, I feare will iſſue thence
The foule corruption of a ſweet childes death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: We cannot hold mortalities ſtrong hand.
Good Lords, although my will to giue, is liuing,
The ſuite which you demand is gone, and dead.
He tels vs Arthur is deceas’d to night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed we fear’d his ſickneſſe was paſt cure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pem.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed we heard how neere his death he was,
Before the childe himſelfe felt he was ſicke:
This muſt be anſwer’d either heere, or hence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SPEECH.LINE: Why do you bend ſuch ſolemne browes on me?
Thinke you I beare the Sheeres of deſtiny?
Haue I commandement on the pulſe of life?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: It is apparant foule-play, and ’tis ſhame
That Greatneſſe ſhould ſo groſſely offer it;
So thriue it in your game, and ſo farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pem.
SPEECH.LINE: Stay yet (Lord Salisbury) Ile go with thee,
And ﬁnde th’ inheritance of this poore childe,
His little kingdome of a forced graue.
That blood which ow’d the bredth of all this Ile,
Three foot of it doth hold; bad world the while:
This muſt not be thus borne, this will breake out
To all our ſorrowes, and ere long I doubt.Exeunt

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Io
SPEECH.LINE: They burn in indignation: I repent:
There is no ſure foundation ſet on blood:
No certaine life atchieu’d by others death:
A fearefull eye thou haſt. Where is that blood,
That I haue ſeene inhabite in thoſe cheekes?
So foule a ſkie, cleeres not without a ſtorme,
Poure downe thy weather: how gœs all in France?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſ.
SPEECH.LINE: From France to England, neuer ſuch a powre
For any forraigne preparation,
Was leuied in the body of a land.
The Copie of your ſpeede is learn’d by them:
For when you ſhould be told they do prepare,
The tydings comes, that they are all arriu’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh where hath our Intelligence bin drunke?
Where hath it ſlept? Where is my Mothers care?
That ſuch an Army could be drawne in France,
And ſhe not heare of it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſ.
SPEECH.LINE: My Liege, her eare
Is ſtopt with duſt: the firſt of Aprill di’de
Your noble mother; and as I heare, my Lord,
The Lady Conſtance in a frenzie di’de
Three dayes before: but this from Rumors tongue
I idely heard: if true, or falſe I know not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: With-hold thy ſpeed, dreadfull Occaſion:
O make a league with me, ’till I haue pleas’d
My diſcontented Peeres. What? Mother dead?
How wildely then walkes my Eſtate in France?
Vnder whoſe conduƈt came thoſe powres of France,
That thou for truth giu’ſt out are landed heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Vnder the Dolphin.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Baſtard and Peter of Pomfret.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou haſt made me giddy
With theſe ill tydings: Now? What ſayes the world
To your proceedings? Do not ſeeke to ſtuffe
My head with more ill newes: for it is full.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: But if you be a-feard to heare the worſt,
Then let the worſt vn-heard, fall on your head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Beare with me Coſen, for I was amaz’d
Vnder the tide; but now I breath againe
Aloﬅ the ﬂood, and can giue audience
To any tongue, ſpeake it of what it will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: How I haue ſped among the Clergy men,
The ſummes I haue colleƈted ſhall expreſſe:
But as I trauail’d hither through the land,
I ﬁnde the people ſtrangely fantaſied,
Poſſeſt with rumors, full of idle dreames,
Not knowing what they feare, but full of feare.
And here’s a Prophet that I brought with me
From forth the ſtreets of Pomfret, whom I found
With many hundreds treading on his heeles:
To whom he ſung in rude harſh ſounding rimes,
That ere the next Aſcenſion day at noone,
Your Highnes ſhould deliuer vp your Crowne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou idle Dreamer, wherefore didſt thou ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pet.
SPEECH.LINE: Fore-knowing that the truth will fall out ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Hubert, away with him: impriſon him,
And on that day at noone, whereon he ſayes
I ſhall yeeld vp my Crowne, let him be hang’d
Deliuer him to ſafety, and returne,
For I muſt vſe thee. O my gentle Coſen,
Hear’ſt thou the newes abroad, who are arriu’d?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: The French (my Lord) mens mouths are ful of it:
Beſides I met Lord Bigot, and Lord Salisburie
With eyes as red as new enkindled fire,
And others more, going to ſeeke the graue
Of Arthur, whom they ſay is kill’d to night, on your ſuggeſtion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Gentle kinſman, go
And thruſt thy ſelfe into their Companies,
I haue a way to winne their loues againe:
Bring them before me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: I will ſeeke them out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, but make haſte: the better foote before.
O, let me haue no ſubieƈt enemies,
When aduerſe Forreyners affright my Townes
With dreadfull pompe of ſtout inuaſion.
Be Mercurie, ſet feathers to thy heeles,
And ﬂye (like thought) from them, to me againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt
SPEECH.LINE: The ſpirit of the time ſhall teach me ſpeed.Exit

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Spoke like a ſprightfull Noble Gentleman.
Go aﬅer him: for he perhaps ſhall neede
Some Meſſenger betwixt me, and the Peeres,
And be thou hee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſ.
SPEECH.LINE: With all my heart, my Liege.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: My mother dead?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, they ſay ﬁue Moones were ſeene to night:
Foure ﬁxed, and the ﬁﬅ did whirle about
The other foure, in wondrous motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SPEECH.LINE: ﬁue Moones?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: Old men, and Beldames, in the ſtreets
Do propheſie vpon it dangerouſly:
Yong Arthurs death is common in their mouths,
And when they talke of him, they ſhake their heads,
And whiſper one another in the eare.
And he that ſpeakes, doth gripe the hearers wriſt,
Whilſt he that heares, makes fearefull aƈtion
With wrinkled browes, with nods, with rolling eyes.
I ſaw a Smith ſtand with his hammer (thus)
The whilſt his Iron did on the Anuile coole,
With open mouth ſwallowing a Taylors newes,
Who with his Sheeres, and Meaſure in his hand,
Standing on ſlippers, which his nimble haſte
Had falſely thruſt vpon contrary feete,
Told of a many thouſand warlike French,
That were embattailed, and rank’d in Kent.
Another leane, vnwaſh’d Artiﬁcer,
Cuts off his tale, and talkes of Arthurs death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Io.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſeek’ſt thou to poſſeſſe me with theſe feares?
Why vrgeſt thou ſo oﬅ yong Arthurs death?
Thy hand hath murdred him: I had a mighty cauſe
To wiſh him dead, but thou hadſt none to kill him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: H.
SPEECH.LINE: No had (my Lord?) why, did you not prouoke me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: It is the curſe of Kings, to be attended
By ſlaues, that take their humors for a warrant,
To breake within the bloody houſe of life,
And on the winking of Authoritie
To vnderſtand a Law; to know the meaning
Of dangerous Maieſty, when perchance it frownes
More vpon humor, then aduis’d reſpeƈt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere is your hand and Seale for what I did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, when the laſt accompt twixt heauen & earth
Is to be made, then ſhall this hand and Seale
Witneſſe againſt vs to damnation.
How oﬅ the ſight of meanes to do ill deeds,
Make deeds ill done? Had’ſt not thou beene by,
A fellow by the hand of Nature mark’d,
Quoted, and ſign’d to do a deede of ſhame,
This murther had not come into my minde.
But taking note of thy abhorr’d Aſpeƈt,
Finding thee ﬁt for bloody villanie:
Apt, liable to be employ’d in danger,
I faintly broke with thee of Arthurs death:
And thou, to be endeered to a King,
Made it no conſcience to deſtroy a Prince.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SPEECH.LINE: Had’ſt thou but ſhooke thy head, or made a pauſe
When I ſpake darkely, what I purpoſed:
Or turn’d an eye of doubt vpon my face;
As bid me tell my tale in expreſſe words:
Deepe ſhame had ſtruck me dumbe, made me break off,
And thoſe thy feares, might haue wrought feares in me.
But, thou didſt vnderſtand me by my ſignes,
And didſt in ſignes againe parley with ſinne,
Yea, without ſtop, didſt let thy heart conſent,
And conſequently, thy rude hand to aƈte
The deed, which both our tongues held vilde to name.
Out of my ſight, and neuer ſee me more:
My Nobles leaue me, and my State is braued,
Euen at my gates, with rankes of forraigne powres;
Nay, in the body of this fleſhly Land,
This kingdome, this Confine of blood, and breathe
Hoſtilitie, and ciuill tumult reignes
Betweene my conſcience, and my Coſins death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: Arme you againſt your other enemies:
Ile make a peace betweene your ſoule, and you.
Yong Arthur is aliue: This hand of mine
Is yet a maiden, and an innocent hand.
Not painted with the Crimſon ſpots of blood,
Within this boſome, neuer entred yet
The dreadfull motion of a murderous thought,
And you haue ſlander’d Nature in my forme,
Which howſœuer rude exteriorly,
Is yet the couer of a fayrer minde,
Then to be butcher of an innocent childe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Doth Arthur liue? O haſt thee to the Peeres,
Throw this report on their incenſed rage,
And make them tame to their obedience.
Forgiue the Comment that my paſſion made
Vpon thy feature, for my rage was blinde,
And foule immaginarie eyes of blood
Preſented thee more hideous then thou art.
Oh, anſwer not; but to my Cloſſet bring
The angry Lords, with all expedient haſt,
I coniure thee but ſlowly: run more faſt.Exeunt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ar.
SPEECH.LINE: The Wall is high, and yet will I leape downe.
Good ground be pittifull, and hurt me not:
There’s few or none do know me, if they did,
This Ship-boyes ſemblance hath diſguis’d me quite.
I am afraide, and yet Ile venture it.
If I get downe, and do not breake my limbes,
Ile ﬁnde a thouſand ſhiﬅs to get away;
As good to dye, and go; as dye, and ſtay.
Oh me, my Vnckles ſpirit is in theſe ſtones,
Heauen take my ſoule, and England keep my bones.Dies

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: Lords, I will meet him at S[aint]. Edmondsbury,
It is our ſafetie, and we muſt embrace
This gentle offer of the perillous time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pem.
SPEECH.LINE: Who brought that Letter from the Cardinall?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: The Count Meloone, a Noble Lord of France,
Whoſe priuate with me of the Dolphines loue,
Is much more generall, then theſe lines import.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Big.
SPEECH.LINE: To morrow morning let vs meete him then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: Or rather then ſet forward, for ’twill be
Two long dayes iourney (Lords) or ere we meete.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Once more to day well met, diſtemper’d Lords,
The King by me requeſts your preſence ſtraight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: The king hath diſpoſſeſt himſelfe of vs,
We will not lyne his thin-beſtained cloake
With our pure Honors: nor attend the foote
That leaues the print of blood where ere it walkes.
Returne, and tell him ſo: we know the worſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: What ere you thinke, good words I thinke were beſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: Our greefes, and not our manners reaſon now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: But there is little reaſon in your greefe.
Therefore ’twere reaſon you had manners now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pem.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, ſir, impatience hath his priuiledge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis true, to hurt his maſter, no mans elſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: This is the priſon: What is he lyes heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: P.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh death, made proud with pure & princely beuty,
The earth had not a hole to hide this deede.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: Murther, as hating what himſelfe hath done,
Doth lay it open to vrge on reuenge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Big.
SPEECH.LINE: Or when he doom’d this Beautie to a graue,
Found it too precious Princely, for a graue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir Richard, what thinke you? you haue beheld,
Or haue you read, or heard, or could you thinke?
Or do you almoſt thinke, although you ſee,
That you do ſee? Could thought, without this obieƈt
Forme ſuch another? This is the very top,
The heighth, the Creſt: or Creſt vnto the Creſt
Of murthers Armes: This is the bloodieſt ſhame,
The wildeſt Sauagery, the vildeſt ſtroke
That euer wall-ey’d wrath, or ſtaring rage
Preſented to the teares of ſoﬅ remorſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pem.
SPEECH.LINE: All murthers paſt, do ſtand excus’d in this:
And this ſo ſole, and ſo vnmatcheable,
Shall giue a holineſſe, a puritie,
To the yet vnbegotten ſinne of times;
And proue a deadly blood-ſhed, but a ieſt,
Exampled by this heynous ſpectacle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: It is a damned, and a bloody worke,
The graceleſſe aƈtion of a heauy hand,
If that it be the worke of any hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: If that it be the worke of any hand?
We had a kinde of light, what would enſue:
It is the ſhamefull worke of Huberts hand,
The praƈtice, and the purpoſe of the king:
From whoſe obedience I forbid my ſoule,
Kneeling before this ruine of ſweete life,
And breathing to his breathleſſe Excellence
The Incenſe of a Vow, a holy Vow:
Neuer to taſte the pleaſures of the world,
Neuer to be infeƈted with delight,
Nor conuerſant with Eaſe, and Idleneſſe,
Till I haue ſet a glory to this hand,
By giuing it the worſhip of Reuenge.
Pem. Big.
Our ſoules religiouſly conﬁrme thy words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: Lords, I am hot with haſte, in ſeeking you,
Arthur doth liue, the king hath ſent for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh he is bold, and bluſhes not at death,
Auant thou hatefull villain, get thee gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hu.
SPEECH.LINE: I am no villaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: Muſt I rob the Law?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Your ſword is bright ſir, put it vp againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: Not till I ſheath it in a murtherers ſkin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: Stand backe Lord Salsbury, ſtand backe I ſay
By heauen, I thinke my ſword’s as ſharpe as yours.
I would not haue you (Lord) forget your ſelfe,
Nor tempt the danger of my true defence;
Lea’t I, by marking of your rage, forget
Your Worth, your Greatneſſe, and Nobility.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Big.
SPEECH.LINE: Out dunghill: dar’ſt thou braue a Nobleman?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: Not for my life: But yet I dare defend
My innocent life againſt an Emperor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art a Murtherer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: Do not proue me ſo:
Yet I am none. Whoſe tongue ſo ere ſpeakes falſe,
Not truely ſpeakes: who ſpeakes not truly, Lies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pem.
SPEECH.LINE: Cut him to peeces.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Keepe the peace, I ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: Stand by, or I ſhall gaul you Faulconbridge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou wer’t better gaul the diuell Salsbury.
If thou but frowne on me, or ſtirre thy foote,
Or teach thy haſtie ſpleene to do me ſhame,
Ile ſtrike thee dead. Put vp thy ſword betime,
Or Ile ſo maule you, and your toſting-Iron,
That you ſhall thinke the diuell is come from hell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Big.
SPEECH.LINE: What wilt thou do, renowned Faulconbridge?
Second a Villaine, and a Murtherer?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: Lord Bigot, I am none.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Big.
SPEECH.LINE: Who kill’d this Prince?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis not an houre ſince I leﬅ him well:
I honour’d him, I lou’d him, and will weepe
My date of life out, for his ſweete liues loſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: Truſt not thoſe cunning waters of his eyes,
For villanie is not without ſuch rheume,
And he, long traded in it, makes it ſeeme
Like Riuers of remorſe and innocencie.
Away with me, all you whoſe ſoules abhorre
Th’ vncleanly ſauours of a Slaughter-houſe,
For I am ſtiﬂed with this ſmell of ſinne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Big.
SPEECH.LINE: Away, toward Burie, to the Dolphin there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: P
SPEECH.LINE: There tel the king, he may inquire vs out. Ex. Lords.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ba.
SPEECH.LINE: Here’s a good world: knew you of this faire work?
Beyond the inﬁnite and boundleſſe reach of mercie,
(If thou didſt this deed of death) art ӳ damn’d Hubert.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: Do but heare me ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha? Ile tell thee what.
Thou’rt damn’d as blacke, nay nothing is ſo blacke,
Thou art more deepe damn’d then Prince Lucifer:
There is not yet ſo vgly a ﬁend of hell
As thou ſhalt be, if thou didſt kill this childe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon my ſoule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: If thou didſt but conſent
To this moſt cruell Aƈt: do but diſpaire,
And if thou want’ſt a Cord, the ſmalleſt thred
That euer Spider twiſted from her wombe
Will ſerue to ſtrangle thee: A ruſh will be a beame
To hang thee on. Or wouldſt thou drowne thy ſelfe,
Put but a little water in a ſpoone,
And it ſhall be as all the Ocean,
Enough to ſtﬂie ſuch a villaine vp.
I do ſuſpeƈt thee very greeuouſly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: If I in aƈt, conſent, or ſinne of thought,
Be guiltie of the ſtealing that ſweete breath
Which was embounded in this beauteous clay,
Let hell want paines enough to torture me:
I leﬅ him well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Go, beare him in thine armes:
I am amaz’d me thinkes, and looſe my way
Among the thornes, and dangers of this world.
How eaſie doſt thou take all England vp,
From forth this morcell of dead Royaltie?
The life, the right, and truth of all this Realme
Is ﬂed to heauen: and England now is leﬂ
To tug and ſcamble, and to part by th’ teeth
The vn-owed intereſt of proud ſwelling State:
Now for the bare-pickt bone of Maieſty,
Doth dogged warre briſtle his angry creſt,
And ſnarleth in the gentle eyes of peace:
Now Powers from home, and diſcontents at home
Meet in one line: and vaſt confuſion waites
As doth a Rauen on a ſicke-falne beaſt,
The iminent decay of wreſted pompe.
Now happy he, whoſe cloake and center can
Hold out this tempeſt. Beare away that childe,
And follow me with ſpeed: Ile to the King:
A thouſand buſineſſes are briefe in hand,
And heauen it ſelfe doth frowne vpon the Land.Exit.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter King Iohn and Pandolph, attendants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: K.Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Thus haue I yeelded vp into your hand
The Circle of my glory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pan.
SPEECH.LINE: Take againe
From this my hand, as holding of the Pope
Your Soueraigne greatneſſe and authoritie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Now keep your holy word, go meet the French,
And from his holineſſe vſe all your power
To ſtop their marches ’fore we are enﬂam’d:
Our diſcontented Counties dœ reuolt:
Our people quarrell with obedience,
Swearing Allegiance, and the loue of ſoule
To ſtranger-bloud, to forren Royalty;
This inundation of miſtempred humor,
Reſts by you onely to be qualiﬁed.
Then pauſe not: for the preſent time’s ſo ſicke,
That preſent medcine muſt be miniſtred,
Or ouerthrow incureable enſues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pand.
SPEECH.LINE: It was my breath that blew this Tempeſt vp,
Vpon your ſtubborne vſage of the Pope:
But ſince you are a gentle conuertite,
My tongue ſhall huſh againe this ſtorme of warre,
And make faire weather in your bluſtring land:
On this Aſcention day, remember well,
Vpon your oath of ſeruice to the Pope,
Gœ I to make the French lay downe their Armes.Exit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Is this Aſcenſion day? did not the Prophet
Say, that before Aſcenſion day at noone,
My Crowne I ſhould giue off? euen ſo I haue:
I did ſuppoſe it ſhould be on conſtraint,
But (heau’n be thank’d) it is but voluntary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: All Kent hath yeelded: nothing there holds out
But Douer Caſtle: London hath receiu’d
Like a kinde Hoſt, the Dolphin and his powers.
Your Nobles will not heare you, but are gone
To offer ſeruice to your enemy:
And wilde amazement hurries vp and downe
The little number of your doubtfull friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Would not my Lords returne to me againe
Aﬅer they heard yong Arthur was aliue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: They found him dead, and caſt into the ſtreets,
An empty Casket, where the Iewell of life
By ſome damn’d hand was rob’d, and tane away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: That villaine Hubert told me he did liue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: So on my ſoule he did, for ought he knew:
But wherefore dœ you droope? why looke you ſad?
Be great in aƈt, as you haue beene in thought:
Let not the world ſee feare and ſad diſtruſt
Gouerne the motion of a kinglye eye:
Be ſtirring as the time, be ﬁre with ﬁre,
Threaten the threatner, and out-face the brow
Of bragging horror: So ſhall inferior eyes
That borrow their behauiours from the great,
Grow great by your example, and put on
The dauntleſſe ſpirit of reſolution.
Away, and gliſter like the god of warre
When he intendeth to become the ﬁeld:
Shew boldneſſe and aſpiring conﬁdence:
What, ſhall they ſeeke the Lion in his denne,
And fright him there? and make him tremble there?
Oh let it not be ſaid: forrage, and runne
To meet diſpleaſure farther from the dores,
And grapple with him ere he come ſo nye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: The Legat of the Pope hath beene with mee,
And I haue made a happy peace with him,
And he hath promis’d to diſmiſſe the Powers
Led by the Dolphin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh inglorious league:
Shall we vpon the footing of our land,
Send fayre-play-orders, and make comprimiſe,
Inſinuation, parley, and baſe truce
To Armes Inuaſiue? Shall a beardleſſe boy,
A cockred-ſilken wanton braue our ﬁelds,
And ﬂeſh his ſpirit in a warre-like ſoyle,
Mocking the ayre with colours idlely ſpred,
And ﬁnde no checke? Let vs my Liege to Armes:
Perchance the Cardinall cannot make your peace;
Or if he dœ, let it at leaſt be ſaid
They ſaw we had a purpoſe of defence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue thou the ordering of this preſent time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Away then with good courage: yet I know
Our Partie may well meet a prowder fœ.Exeunt.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter (in Armes) Dolphin, Salisbury, Meloone, Pembroke, Bigot, Souldiers

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dol.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord Melloone, let this be coppied out,
And keepe it ſafe for our remembrance:
Returne the preſident to theſe Lords againe,
That hauing our faire order written downe,
Both they and we, peruſing ore theſe notes
May know wherefore we tooke the Sacrament,
And keepe our faithes ﬁrme and inuiolable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon our ſides it neuer ſhall be broken.
And Noble Dolphin, albeit we ſweare
A voluntary zeale, and an vn-urg’d Faith
To your proceedings: yet beleeue me Prince,
I am not glad that ſuch a ſore of Time
Should ſeeke a plaſter by contemn’d reuolt,
And heale the inueterate Canker of one wound,
By making many: Oh it grieues my ſoule,
That I muſt draw this mettle from my ſide
To be a widdow-maker: oh, and there
Where honourable reſcue, and defence
Cries out vpon the name of Salisbury.
But ſuch is the infeƈtion of the time,
That for the health and Phyſicke of our right,
We cannot deale but with the very hand
Of ſterne Iniuſtice, and confuſed wrong:
And is’t not pitty, (oh my grieued friends)
That we, the ſonnes and children of this Iſle,
Was borne to ſee ſo ſad an houre as this,
Wherein we ſtep aﬅer a ſtranger, march
Vpon her gentle boſom, and fill vp
Her Enemies rankes? I muſt withdraw, and weepe
Vpon the ſpot of this inforced cauſe,
To grace the Gentry of a Land remote,
And follow vnacquainted colours heere:
What heere? O Nation that thou couldſt remoue,
That Neptunes Armes who clippeth thee about,
Would beare thee from the knowledge of thy ſelfe,
And cripple thee vnto a Pagan ſhore,
Where theſe two Chriſtian Armies might combine
The bloud of malice, in a vaine of league,
And not to ſpend it ſo vn-neighbourly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dolph.
SPEECH.LINE: A noble temper doſt thou ſhew in this,
And great affeƈtions wraſtling in thy boſome
Doth make an earth-quake of Nobility:
Oh, what a noble combat haſt fought
Between compulſion, and a braue reſpeƈt:
Let me wipe off this honourable dewe,
That ſiluerly doth progreſſe on thy cheekes:
My heart hath melted at a Ladies teares,
Being an ordinary Inundation:
But this effuſion of ſuch manly drops,
This ſhowre, blowne vp by tempeſt of the ſoule,
Startles mine eyes, and makes me more amaz’d
Then had I ſeene the vaultie top of heauen
Figur’d quite ore with burning Meteors.
Liﬅ vp thy brow (renowned Salisburie)
And with a great heart heaue away this ſtorme:
Commend theſe waters to thoſe baby-eyes
That neuer ſaw the giant-world enrag’d,
Nor met with Fortune, other then at feaſts,
Full warm of blood, of mirth, of goſſipping:
Come, come; for thou ſhalt thruſt thy hand as deepe
Into the purſe of rich proſperity
As Lewis himſelfe: ſo (Nobles) ſhall you all,
That knit your ſinewes to the ſtrength of mine.
And euen there, methinkes an Angell ſpake,
Looke where the holy Legate comes apace,
To giue vs warrant from the hand of heauen,
And on our aſƈtions ſet the name of right
With holy breath.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pand.
SPEECH.LINE: Haile noble Prince of France:
The next is this: King Iohn hath reconcil’d
Himſelfe to Rome, his ſpirit is come in,
That ſo ſtood out againſt the holy Church,
The great Metropolis and Sea of Rome:
Therefore thy threatning Colours now winde vp,
And tame the ſauage ſpirit of wilde warre,
That like a Lion foſtered vp at hand,
It may lie gently at the foot of peace,
And be no further harmefull then in ſhewe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dol.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Grace ſhall pardon me, I will not backe:
I am too high-borne to be proportied
To be a ſecondary at controll,
Or vſefull ſeruing-man, and Inſtrument
To any Soueraigne State throughout the world.
Your breath firſt kindled the dead coale of warres,
Betweene this chaſtiz’d kingdome and my ſelfe,
And brought in matter that ſhould feed this ﬁre;
And now ’tis farre too huge to be blowne out
With that ſame weake winde, which enkindled it:
You taught me how to know the face of right,
Acquainted me with intereſt to this Land,
Yea, thruſt this enterprize into my heart,
And come ye now to tell me Iohn hath made
His peace with Rome? what is that peace to me?
I (by the honour of my marriage bed)
Aﬅer yong Arthur, claime this Land for mine,
And now it is halfe conquer’d, muſt I backe,
Becauſe that Iohn hath made his peace with Rome?
Am I Romes ſlaue? What penny hath Rome borne?
What men prouided? What munition ſent
To vnder-prop this Aƈtion? Is’t not I
That vnder-gœ this charge? Who elſe but I,
And ſuch as to my claime are liable,
Sweat in this buſineſſe, and maintaine this warre?
Haue I not heard theſe Iſlanders ſhout out
Viue le Roy, as I haue bank’d their Townes?
Haue I not heere the beſt Cards for the game
To winne this eaſie match, plaid for a Crowne?
And ſhall I now giue ore the yeelded Set?
No, no, on my ſoule it neuer ſhall be ſaid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pand.
SPEECH.LINE: You looke but on the out-ſide of this worke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dol.
SPEECH.LINE: Out-ſide or in-ſide, I will not returne
Till my attempt ſo much be gloriﬁed,
As to my ample hope was promiſed,
Before I drew this gallant head of warre,
And cull’d theſe ﬁery ſpirits from the world
To out-looke Conqueſt, and to winne renowne
Euen in the iawes of danger, and of death:
What luſty Trumpet thus doth ſummon vs?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: According to the faire-play of the world,
Let me haue audience: I am ſent to ſpeake:
My holy Lord of Millane, from the King
I come to learne how you haue dealt for him:
And, as you anſwer, I dœ know the ſcope
And warrant limited vnto my tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pand.
SPEECH.LINE: The Dolphin is too wilfull oppoſite
And will not temporize with my intreaties:
He ﬂatly ſaies, hee’ll not lay downe his Armes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: By all the bloud that euer fury breath’d,
The youth ſaies well. Now heare our Engliſh King,
For thus his Royaltie doth ſpeake in me:
He is prepar’d, and reaſon to he ſhould,
This apiſh and vnmannerly approach,
This harneſſ’d Maſke, and vnaduiſed Reuell,
This vn-heard ſawcineſſe and boyiſh Troopes,
The King doth ſmile at, and is well prepar’d
To whip this dwarfiſh warre, this Pigmy Armes
From out the circle of his Territories.
That hand which had the ſtrength, euen at your dore,
To cudgell you, and make you take the hatch,
To diue like Buckets in concealed Welles,
To crowch in litter of your ſtable plankes,
To lye like pawnes, lock’d vp in cheſts and truncks,
To hug with ſwine, to ſeeke ſweet ſafety out
In vaults and priſons, and to thrill and ſhake,
Euen at the crying of your Nations crow,
Thinking this voyce an armed Engliſhman.
Shall that viƈtorious hand be feebled heere,
That in your Chambers gaue you chaſticement?
No: know the gallant Monarch is in Armes,
And like an Eagle, o’re his ayerie towres,
To ſowſſe annoyance that comes neere his Neſt;
And you degenerate, you ingrate Reuolts,
You bloudy Nero’s, ripping vp the wombe
Of your deere Mother-England: bluſh for ſhame:
For your owne Ladies, and pale-viſag’d Maides,
Like Amazons, come tripping aﬅer drummes:
Their thimbles into armed Gantlets change,
Their Needl’s to Lances, and their gentle hearts
To ﬁerce and bloody inclination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dol.
SPEECH.LINE: There end thy braue, and turn thy face in peace,
We grant thou canſt out-ſcold vs: Far thee well,
We hold our time too precious to be ſpent
with ſuch a brabler.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pan.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue me leaue to ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: No, I will ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dol.
SPEECH.LINE: We will attend to neyther:
Strike vp the drummes, and let the tongue of warre
Pleade for our intereſt, and our being heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeede your drums being beaten, wil cry out;
And ſo ſhall you, being beaten: Do but ſtart
An eccho with the clamor of thy drumme,
And euen at hand, a drumme is readie brac’d,
That ſhall reuerberate all, as lowd as thine.
Sound but another, and another ſhall
(As lowd as thine) rattle the Welkins eare,
And mocke the deepe mouth’d Thunder: for at hand
(Not truſting to this halting Legate heere,
Whom he hath vs’d rather for ſport, then neede)
Is warlike Iohn: and in his fore-head ſits
A bare-rib’d death, whoſe ofﬁce is this day
To feaſt vpon whole thouſands of the French.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dol.
SPEECH.LINE: Strike vp our drummes, to finde this danger out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: And thou ſhalt finde it (Dolphin) do not doubt

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: How gœs the day with vs? oh tell me Hubert.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: Badly I feare; how fares your Maieſty?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: This Feauer that hath troubled me ſo long,
Lyes heauie on me: oh, my heart is ſicke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſ.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord: your valiant kinſman Falconbridge,
Deſires your Maieſtie to leaue the field,
And ſend him word by me, which way you go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Tell him toward Swinſted, to the Abbey there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Be of good comfort: for the great ſupply
That was expeƈted by the Dolphin heere,
Are wrack’d three nights ago on Goodwin ſands.
This newes was brought to Richard but euen now,
The French ﬁght coldly, and retyre themselues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Aye me, this tyrant Feauer burnes mee vp,
And will not let me welcome this good newes.
Set on toward Swinſted: to my Litter ſtraight,
Weakneſſe poſſeſſeth me, and I am faint.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: I did not thinke the King ſo ſtor’d with friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pem.
SPEECH.LINE: Vp once againe: put ſpirit in the French,
If they miſcarry: we miſcarry too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: That miſbegotten diuell Falconbridge,
In ſpight of ſpight, alone vpholds the day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pem.
SPEECH.LINE: They ſay King Iohn ſore ſick, hath leﬅ the ﬁeld.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mel.
SPEECH.LINE: Lead me to the Reuolts of England heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: When we were happie, we had other names.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pem.
SPEECH.LINE: It is the Count Meloone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: Wounded to death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mel.
SPEECH.LINE: Fly Noble Engliſh, you are bought and ſold,
Vnthred the rude eye of Rebellion,
And welcome home againe diſcarded faith,
Seeke out King Iohn, and fall before his feete:
For if the French be Lords of this loud day,
He meanes to recompence the paines you take,
By cutting off your heads: Thus hath he ſworne,
And I with him, and many mœ with mee,
Vpon the Altar at S[aint]. Edmondsbury,
Euen on that Altar, where we ſwore to you
Deere Amity, and euerlaſting loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: May this be poſſible? May this be true?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mel.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue I not hideous death within my view,
Retaining but a quantity of life,
Which bleeds away, euen as a forme of waxe
Reſolueth from his ﬁgure ’gainſt the ﬁre?
What in the world ſhould make me now deceiue,
Since I muſt looſe the vſe of all deceite?
Why ſhould I then be falſe, ſince it is true
That I muſt dye heere, and liue hence, by Truth?
I ſay againe, if Lewis do win the day,
He is forſworne, if ere thoſe eyes of yours
Behold another day breake in the Eaſt:
But euen this night, whoſe blacke contagious breath
Already ſmoakes about the burning Creſt
Of the old, feeble, and day-wearied Sunne,
Euen this ill night, your breathing ſhall expire,
Paying the ﬁne of rated Treachery,
Euen with a treacherous ﬁne of all your liues:
If Lewis, by your aſſiſtance win the day.
Commend me to one Hubert, with your King;
The loue of him, and this reſpeƈt beſides
(For that my Grandſire was an Engliſhman)
Awakes my Conſcience to confeſſe all this.
In lieu whereof, I pray you beare me hence
From forth the noiſe and rumour of the Field;
Where I may thinke the remnant of my thoughts
In peace: and part this bodie and my ſoule
With contemplation, and deuout deſires.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: We do beleeue thee, and beſhrew my ſoule,
But I do loue the fauour, and the forme
Of this moſt faire occaſion, by the which
We will vntread the ſteps of damned ﬂight,
And like a bated and retired Flood,
Leauing our rankneſſe and irregular courſe,
Stoope lowe within thoſe bounds we haue ore-look’d,
And calmely run on in obedience
Euen to our Ocean, to our great King Iohn.
My arme ſhall giue thee helpe to beare thee hence,
For I do ſee the cruell pangs of death
Right in thine eye. Away, my friends, new ﬂight,
And happie newneſſe, that intends old right.Exeunt

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dol.
SPEECH.LINE: The Sun of heauen (me thought) was loth to ſet;
But ſtaid, and made the Weſterne Welkin bluſh,
When Engliſh meaſure backward their owne ground
In faint Retire: Oh brauely came we off,
When with a volley of our needleſſe ſhot,
Aﬅer ſuch bloody toile, we bid good night,
And woon’d our tott’ring colours clearly vp,
Laſt in the ﬁeld, and almoſt Lords of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is my Prince, the Dolphin?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dol.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere: what newes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſ.
SPEECH.LINE: The Count Meloone is ſlaine: The Engliſh Lords
By his perſwaſion, are againe falne off,
And your ſupply, which you haue wiſh’d ſo long,
Are caſt away, and ſunke on Goodwin ſands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dol.
SPEECH.LINE: Ah fowle, ſhrew’d newes. Beſhrew thy very hart:
I did not thinke to be ſo ſad to night
As this hath made me. Who was he that ſaid
King Iohn did ﬂie an houre or two before
The ſtumbling night did part our wearie powres?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Who euer ſpoke it, it is true my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dol.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: keepe good quarter, & good care to night,
The day ſhall not be vp ſo ſoone as I,
To try the faire aduenture of to morrow.Exeunt

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: Whoſe there? Speake hoa, ſpeake quickely, or
I ſhoote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: A Friend. What art thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: Of the part of England.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Whether dœſt thou go?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: What’s that to thee?
Why may not I demand of thine affaires,
As well as thou of mine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Hubert, I thinke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou haſt a perfeƈt thought:
I will vpon all hazards well beleeue
Thou art my friend, that know’ſt my tongue ſo well:
Who art thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Who thou wilt: and if thou pleaſe
Thou maiſt be-friend me ſo much, as to thinke
I come one way of the Plantagenets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: Vnkinde remembrance: thou, & endles night,
Haue done me ſhame: Braue Soldier, pardon me,
That any accent breaking from thy tongue,
Should ſcape the true acquaintance of mine eare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come: ſans complement, What newes
abroad?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: Why heere walke I in the black brow of night
To finde you out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Breefe then: and what’s the newes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: O my ſweet ſir, newes ﬁtting to the night,
Blacke, fearefull, comfortleſſe, and horrible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Shew me the very wound of this ill newes,
I am no woman, Ile not ſwound at it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: The King I feare is poyſon’d by a Monke,
I leﬅ him almoſt ſpeechleſſe, and broke out
To acquaint you with this euill, that you might
The better arme you to the ſodaine time,
Then if you had at leiſure knowne of this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: How did he take it? Who did taſte to him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: A Monke I tell you, a reſolued villaine
Whoſe Bowels ſodainly burſt out: The King
Yet ſpeakes, and peraduenture may recouer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Who didſt thou leaue to tend his Maieſty?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hub.
SPEECH.LINE: Why know you not? The Lords are all come backe,
And brought Prince Henry in their companie,
At whoſe requeſt the king hath pardon’d them,
And they are all about his Maieſtie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: With-hold thine indignation, mighty heauen,
And tempt vs not to beare aboue our power.
Ile tell thee Hubert, halfe my power this night
Paſsing theſe Flats, are taken by the Tide,
Theſe Lincolne-Waſhes haue deuoured them,
My ſelfe, well mounted, hardly haue eſcap’d.
Away before: Conduƈt me to the king,
I doubt he will be dead, or ere I come.Exeunt

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Prince Henry, Salisburie, and Bigot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hen.
SPEECH.LINE: It is too late, the life of all his blood
Is touch’d, corruptibly: and his pure braine
(Which ſome ſuppoſe the ſoules fraile dwelling houſe)
Doth by the idle Comments that it makes,
Fore-tell the ending of mortality.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pem.
SPEECH.LINE: His Highneſſe yet doth ſpeak, & holds beleefe,
That being brought into the open ayre,
It would allay the burning qualitie
Of that fell poiſon which aſſayleth him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hen.
SPEECH.LINE: Let him be brought into the Orchard heere:
Doth he ſtill rage?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pem.
SPEECH.LINE: He is more patient
Then when you leﬅ him; euen now he ſung.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hen.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh vanity of ſickneſſe: ﬁerce extreames
In their continuance, will not feele themſelues.
Death hauing praide vpon the outward parts
Leaues them inuiſible, and his ſeige is now
Againſt the winde, the which he prickes and wounds
With many legions of ſtrange fantaſies,
Which in their throng, and preſſe to that laſt hold,
Counfound themſelues. ’Tis ſtrange ý death ſhold ſing:
I am the Symet to this pale faint Swan,
Who chaunts a dolefull hymne to his owne death,
And from the organ-pipe of frailety ſings
His ſoule and body to their laſting reſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: Be of good comfort (Prince) for you are borne
To ſet a forme vpon that indigeſt
Which he hath leﬅ ſo ſhapeleſſe, and ſo rude.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: I marrie, now my ſoule hath elbow roome,
It would not out at windowes, nor at doores,
There is ſo hot a ſummer in my boſome,
That all my bowels crumble vp to duſt:
I am a ſcribled forme drawne with a pen
Vpon a Parchment, and againſt this fire
Do I ſhrinke vp.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hen.
SPEECH.LINE: How fares your Maieſty?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ioh.
SPEECH.LINE: Poyſon’d, ill fare: dead, forſooke, caſt off,
And none of you will bid the winter come
To thruſt his ycie ﬁngers in my maw;
Nor let my kingdomes Riuers take their courſe
Through my burn’d boſome: nor intreat the North
To make his bleake windes kiſſe my parched lips,
And comfort me with cold. I do not aske you much,
I begge cold comfort: and you are ſo ſtraight
And ſo ingratefull, you deny me that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hen.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh that there were ſome vertue in my teares,
That might releeue you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſalt in them is hot.
Within me is a hell, and there the poyſon
Is, as a ﬁend, conﬁn’d to tyrannize,
On vnrepreeuable condemned blood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, I am ſcalded with my violent motion
And ſpleene of ſpeede, to ſee your Maieſty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iohn.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh Cozen, thou art come to ſet mine eye:
The tackle of my heart, is crack’d and burnt,
And all the ſhrowds wherewith my life ſhould ſaile,
Are turned to one thred, one little haire:
My heart hath one poore ſtring to ſtay it by,
Which holds but till thy newes be vttered,
And then all this thou ſeeſt, is but a clod,
And module of confounded royalty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: The Dolphin is preparing hither-ward,
Where heauen he knowes how we ſhall anſwer him.
For in a night the beſt part of my powre,
As I vpon aduantage did remoue,
Were in the Waſhes all vnwarily,
Deuoured by the vnexpeƈted ﬂood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: You breath theſe dead newes in as dead an eare
My Liege, my Lord: but now a King, now thus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hen.
SPEECH.LINE: Euen ſo muſt I run on, and euen ſo ſtop.
What ſurety of the world, what hope, what ſtay,
When this was now a King, and now is clay?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Art thou gone ſo? I do but ſtay behinde,
To do the ofﬁce for thee, of reuenge,
And then my ſoule ſhall waite on thee to heauen,
As it on earth hath bene thy ſeruant ſtill.
Now, now you Starres, that moue in your right ſpheres,
Where be your powres? Shew now your mended faiths,
And inſtantly returne with me againe.
To puſh deſtruƈtion, and perpetuall ſhame
Out of the weake doore of our fainting Land:
Straight let vs ſeeke, or ſtraight we ſhall be ſought,
The Dolphine rages at our verie heeles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: It ſeemes you know not then ſo much as we,
The Cardinall Pandulph is within at reſt,
Who halfe an houre ſince came from the Dolphin,
And brings from him ſuch offers of our peace,
As we with honor and reſpeƈt may take,
With purpoſe preſently to leaue this warre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: He will the rather do it, when he ſees
Our ſelues well ſinew’d to our defence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, ’tis in a manner done already,
For many carriages hee hath diſpatch’d
To the ſea ſide, and put his cauſe and quarrell
To the diſpoſing of the Cardinall,
With whom your ſelfe, my ſelfe, and other Lords,
If you thinke meete, this aﬅernoone will poaſt
To conſummate this buſineſſe happily.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Let it be ſo, and you my noble Prince,
With other Princes that may beſt be ſpar’d,
Shall waite vpon your Fathers Funerall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hen.
SPEECH.LINE: At Worſter muſt his bodie be interr’d,
For ſo he will’d it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Thither ſhall it then,
And happily may your ſweet ſelfe put on
The lineall ſtate, and glorie of the Land,
To whom with all ſubmiſsion on my knee,
I do bequeath my faithfull ſeruices
And true ſubieƈtion euerlaſtingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: And the like tender of our loue wee make
To reſt without a ſpot for euermore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hen.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue a kinde ſoule, that would giue thankes,
And knowes not how to do it, but with teares.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh let vs pay the time: but needfull wœ,
Since it hath beene before hand with our greefes.
This England neuer did, nor neuer ſhall
Lye at the proud foote of a Conqueror,
But when it firſt did helpe to wound it ſelfe.
Now, theſe her Princes are come home againe,
Come the three corners of the world in Armes,
And we ſhall ſhocke them: Naught ſhall make vs rue,
If England to it ſelfe, do reſt but true.Exeunt.
